newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada apologizes to Micmac Indian on feather.
newsitem.headline: Canada apologizes to Micmac Indian on feather.

text.p: Canada's House of Commons apologized on Wednesday to a Micmac Indian teen-ager who was stopped from entering the House of Commons for holding an eagle feather.
"I extend the apologies of this house," Gilbert Parent, the speaker of the House, said on Wednesday.

Melissa Labrador, 17, was stopped from entering the public gallery of the House of Commons on Tuesday after a guard told her she might injure somebody by throwing the feather at members of Parliament seated below the gallery.
"Of course it is permissible for an aboriginal to bring a feather into this house. It was a mistake. It will not happen again," he said, adding that he has aboriginal roots too.
Spectators have not usually been allowed to bring anything into the gallery, the speaker's office said.

The young Indian from Nova Scotia, in Ottawa for the first time to participate in a youth forum, left Parliament in tears. "I wanted to hold the feather to show people that I am aboriginal," she told the Ottawa Citizen. "I'm not going to hide who I am."

She said she brought the feather to fight homesickness during her visit to the big city. "It means a lot to me because the eagle flies closest to the creator, above the clouds," she told the newspaper.
One guard did eventually decide to allow Labrador in the House, but she declined.
